attributes.Attribute description:
Record a carriageway label for each section of road to distinguish which carriageway is being coded.
Undivided vs. divided carriageways: Divided (dual) carriageways are surveyed in both directions, but undivided (single) carriageway roads are recorded in one direction only, even if the traffic is two-way. What is considered divided and undivided depends on the median type and its length:
- Divided carriageways are those that physically separate opposing traffic flows by either a barrier or a wide physical median consistently and for a distance of 400m or more.
- An undivided carriageway has no physical separation between opposing traffic flows, or physically separates traffic for a section of less than 400m.
- One-way roads must be coded as undivided and the Median type set to one-way.
- Service roads must be coded separately to the main carriageways. Code service roads the same way as standard roads.
- If a bus or transit lane is part of the main carriageway, code it as part of the carriageway (see instructions on coding transit lanes under Number of lanes). Where there is a dedicated, separated carriageway for buses, these should be coded as divided or undivided carriageways separate to the main carriageway

categories.Category: Carriageway A of a divided road
categories.Category_description: Divided carriageway in one direction.

categories.Category: Carriageway B of a divided road
categories.Category_description: Divided carriageway in opposite direction (to carriageway A).
Undivided carriageway (in both directions or one-way).

categories.Category: Carriageway A of a motorcycle facility
categories.Category_description: Segregated motorcycle paths adjacent to the main carriageway.

categories.Category: Carriageway B of a motorcycle facility
categories.Category_description: Segregated motorcycle paths adjacent to the main carriageway.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the influence that the surrounding land-use, environment and topography will have on the cost of major works.
Upgrade Cost is based on the relative cost of acquiring additional land and the associated complexity of working on that land. Upgrade cost may be designated as:
-'High' where the cost of purchasing land or developing it would be relatively expensive.
-'Medium' where the cost of purchasing land or developing it would be relatively moderate.
-'Low' where the cost of purchasing land or developing it would be relatively low.

categories.Category_description:
The cost of road upgrades, such as adding a lane, would be relatively high. For example:
- Major earthworks will be required.
- Major service relocations expected.
- Major property or adjacent developments affected, such as in urban areas.

The cost of road upgrades, such as adding a lane, would be relatively moderate. For example:
- Moderate earthworks required.
 -Minor adjacent developments will be affected.

The cost of road upgrades, such as adding a lane, would be relatively low. For example:
- Minimal earthworks required.
- No fringe development..

attributes.Attribute description: Record the number of motorcycles observed within the coding segment. A motorcycle is a motorised two or three-wheeled vehicle. This typically includes mopeds, scooters and light three- and four-wheel vehicles capable of speeds over 30km/h. Motorcycles which are parked or not in use should not be recorded.
Record the number of bicycles observed within the coding segment. A bicycle is a two- or three-wheeled pedal, pedal-assisted or mobility vehicle limited to speeds of less than 30km/h.

attributes.Item: Pedestrian observed flow across the road
attributes.Attribute description: Record the number of pedestrians across the road observed within the coding segment. Pedestrians include anyone on foot, operating a push/pull vehicle (street cleaner, pram or rickshaw) or in a wheelchair or other mobility vehicle. Do not count people involved in temporary road maintenance or construction.

attributes.Item: Pedestrian observed flow along the road driver-side
attributes.Attribute description: Record the number of pedestrians along the driver-side of the road observed within the coding segment. Pedestrians include anyone on foot, operating a push/pull vehicle (street cleaner, pram or rickshaw) or in a wheelchair or other mobility vehicle. Do not count people involved in temporary road maintenance or construction.

attributes.Item: Pedestrian observed flow along the road passenger-side
attributes.Attribute description: Record the number of pedestrians along the passenger-side of the road observed within the coding segment. Pedestrians include anyone on foot, operating a push/pull vehicle (street cleaner, pram or rickshaw) or in a wheelchair or other mobility vehicle. Do not count people involved in temporary road maintenance or construction.

Record the type of roadside development that is observed on the driver-side.
Only record land use types where there are clearly identifiable shorter lengths of high intensity activity, such as schools, short lengths of village environment, or localised market sites on rural roads.
Any areas of obvious potential high intensity pedestrian activity should be coded as ‘commercial’ even if commercial activity is not immediately obvious.
If in doubt between two land use categories, select the one that appears first in the list of coding options.
If a road, such as a motorway overpass, cannot be accessed by pedestrians, code it as ‘undeveloped areas’. However, if pedestrians are present or are known to use the overpass, code it according to its surrounding land use. 

  If 1.<Attribute>: Carriageway is recorded as 'Carriageway A of a divided road', this attribute should be recorded as 'Undeveloped areas'.

categories.Category_description: Schools, colleges, universities or other facilities that generate high pedestrian flows, such as hospitals or sporting arenas, are present.
Shops or other commercial activity, parks and recreation spaces (such as sporting fields) or areas where high intensity pedestrian activity is evident. Include all types of shopping precincts.
Industrial units, factories and/or manufacturing sites are present.
Residential housing area is present.
Land used for farming or agricultural activities is present. Do not include open pasture with very low or no activity around it.

Open land without shops, housing, industry or farming or where there is no land adjacent to the road.For example, bridges across water, elevated highways (without pedestrian access), overpasses and tunnels.
Not Recorded

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the type of roadside development that is observed on the driver-side.
Only record land use types where there are clearly identifiable shorter lengths of high intensity activity, such as schools, short lengths of village environment, or localised market sites on rural roads.
Any areas of obvious potential high intensity pedestrian activity should be coded as ‘commercial’ even if commercial activity is not immediately obvious.
If in doubt between two land use categories, select the one that appears first in the list of coding options.
If a road, such as a motorway overpass, cannot be accessed by pedestrians, code it as ‘undeveloped areas’. However, if pedestrians are present or are known to use the overpass, code it according to its surrounding land use.

categories.Category_description: Schools, colleges, universities or other facilities that generate high pedestrian flows, such as hospitals or sporting arenas, are present.
Shops or other commercial activity, parks and recreation spaces (such as sporting fields) or areas where high intensity pedestrian activity is evident. Include all types of shopping precincts.
Industrial units, factories and/or manufacturing sites are present.
Residential housing area is present.
Land used for farming or agricultural activities is present. Do not include open pasture with very low or no activity around it.

Open land without shops, housing, industry or farming or where there is no land adjacent to the road.For example, bridges across water, elevated highways (without pedestrian access), overpasses and tunnels.
Not Recorded

attributes.Attribute description: Record the type of area surrounding the road. Area type is coded as being either ‘urban’ or ‘rural’ depending on the level surrounding development. Town limit signs may be used as a guide.

categories.Category_description: Development spanning at least 400 metres along the road. Small, isolated settlements of less than 400m may be coded as changes to land use where they are sites of high intensity activity, such as schools, short lengths of village environment, or localised market sites.
Area outside of an urban area or rural town or village, or where roadside development does not impact the road or where it is separated by a large fence or wall.

attributes.Attribute description: Record the actual posted numerical speed limit for general traffic. If no speed limit is posted, or there is a state/national limit sign, the default speed limit set by law for that type of road should be used. Do not record temporary speed limits at road works or school zones. Do not record advisory speeds.

Record the actual posted numerical speed limit for motorcycle. If no speed limit is posted, or there is a state/national limit sign, the default speed limit set by law for that type of road should be used. Do not record temporary speed limits at road works or school zones. Do not record advisory speeds.

Record the actual posted numerical speed limit for truck. If no speed limit is posted, or there is a state/national limit sign, the default speed limit set by law for that type of road should be used. Do not record temporary speed limits at road works or school zones. Do not record advisory speeds.

Record if the difference in speed (operating or speed limit) between the posted speed limits for general traffic (<Attribute>: Speed limit), motorcycles (<Attribute>: Motorcycle speed limit), and trucks (<Attribute>: Truck speed limit) exceeds 20km/h or 12mph. The calculation should be based on the <Category class> values selected for the related speed limit attributes.

Task:
Step 1: Retrieve the selected <Category class> values for the <Attribute>: Speed limit, <Attribute>: Motorcycle speed limit, and <Attribute>: Truck speed limit.
Step 2: Calculate the difference in speed between each pair (Speed limit vs. Motorcycle speed limit, Speed limit vs. Truck speed limit).
Step 3: Determine if any of these differences exceed 20km/h or 12mph.
Step 4: If any difference exceeds 20km/h or 12mph, return the <Category class>: Present. If all differences are 20km/h or 12mph or less, return <Category class>: Not present.

Example Calculation: If <Attribute>: Speed limit is 140km/h and <Attribute>: Motorcycle speed limit is 80km/h, the difference is 60km/h. Since this is greater than 20km/h, the <Category class>: Present should be selected.

categories.Category_description: Difference in operating speed or speed limit is greater than 20km/h or 12mph.
Difference in operating speed or speed limit is equal to or less than 20km/h or 12mph.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the road infrastructure feature that separates the two opposing traffic flows for both divided and undivided carriageways.
- Note: Median fencing used to control traffic and pedestrian movement, but that would not withstand vehicle impact, should be recorded as 'Flexible posts'.
- Undivided Roads: If the road is undivided, has two directions of travel, and has no markings, it should be recorded as 'Median type = Centre line only' and 'Delineation = Poor'.

categories.Category_description: Undivided two-way road only. Single or double central line or marked central strip that is less than 0.3m wide. The centre line can be either dashed or solid, and of any colour.
Undivided two-way road only. Single or double centre line, or marked central strip 0.3m to 1m wide. The wide centre line may be dashed, solid or ladder hatching, and of any colour.
Undivided two-way road only. Marked central strip greater than 1m wide. Examples of marking are ladder hatching, stripes or coloured paving.
Undivided two-way road only. Continuous central lane designated as a turning lane.

Undivided two-way road only. Flexible posts or bollards, but that are not a continuous physical divider. May include median fences installed for the purposes of controlling traffic and pedestrian movements, but which would not withstand vehicle impact.
Divided road only. Defined median of different material less than 1m wide. A physical median typically includes a curb or other surface change that would slow an out-of-control vehicle.
Divided road only. Defined median of different material 1m to <5m wide. A physical median typically includes a curb or other surface change that would slow an out-of-control vehicle.
Divided road only. Defined median of different material 5m to <10m wide. A physical median typically includes a curb or other surface change that would slow an out-of-control vehicle.
Divided road only. Safety barrier constructed from concrete that meets international standards. Do not record defective safety barriers.
Divided road only. Metal safety barrier that meets international standards. Do not record defective safety barriers.

Divided road only. Safety barrier designed to minimise impact to motorcyclists that meets international standards. Motorcycle friendly barriers will have some form of protection for the supporting post or legs.
Divided road only. Safety barrier constructed from tensioned wires that meets international standards.Do not record defective safety barriers.
Divided road only. Defined median of different material 10m to less than 20m wide. A physical median typically includes a curb or other surface change that would slow an out-of-control vehicle.
Divided road only. Defined median of different material 20m wide or more. A physical median typically includes a curb or other surface change that would slow an out-of-control vehicle.
One-way road only. Vehicles travel in a single direction with no opposing flow.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record any textured markings along the centre of an undivided road which function to warn drivers crossing the median.
Centreline rumble strips should be coded only for undivided roads where there structured or milled markings as part of the road marking median. Only record centre line rumble strips where they are present for the whole coding segment, except where an intersection is present. Do not record shoulder rumble strips here.
Centre line rumble strips are also known as raised profile markings. This feature provides an audio-vibratory warning to the driver. They may be a solid line or placed intermittently (similar to a dashed line). Rumble strips may be either grooves cut into the pavement surface or raised ribs added to the road marking. Raised markers that are spaced between 10-20 cm and serve a similar purpose may also be recorded.
Centre line rumble strips should only be recorded where delineation is present.

categories.Category_description: Rumble strip is not present in the centre of the road.
Rumble strip is present in the centre of the road.

attributes.Attribute description:
Examine the roadside environment on the driver-side of the image to identify hazardous objects that pose a risk to vehicles. Follow these steps:
1.Identify Hazardous Objects: Look for any objects on the driver-side that could be dangerous to vehicles, such as barriers, trees, poles, structures, or slopes.
2. Measure Distance: Estimate the distance from the edge line of the nearest driving lane to the identified hazardous object(s).
3.Classify Hazards: Categorize the identified hazards using the provided risk hierarchy, with #1 being the highest risk:
#1 Any - Cliff
#2 0 to <1m - Tree ≥10cm
#3 0 to <1m - Rigid sign, post or pole ≥10cm
#4 0 to <1m - Rigid structure or building
#5 0 to <1m - Unprotected safety barrier end
#6 0 to <1m - Low rigid object ≥20cm high
#7 0 to <1m - Aggressive vertical face
#8 0 to <1m - Deep drainage ditch
#9 1 to <5m - Tree ≥10cm
#10 1 to <5m - Rigid sign, post or pole ≥10cm
#11 1 to <5m - Rigid structure or building
#12 1 to <5m - Unprotected safety barrier end
#13 1 to <5m - Low rigid object ≥20cm high
#14 0 to <1m - Upwards slope - roll over
#15 0 to <1m - Downwards slope
#16 1 to <5m - Aggressive vertical face
#17 1 to <5m - Deep drainage ditch
#18 0 to <1m - Upwards slope - no roll over
#19 0 to <1m - Upwards slope - roll over
#20 1 to <5m - Downwards slope
#21 0 to <1m - Upwards slope - no roll over
#22 0 to <1m - Semi-rigid structure or building
#23 1 to <5m - Semi-rigid structure or building
#24 5 to <10m - Tree ≥10cm
#25 5 to <10m - Rigid sign, post or pole ≥10cm
#26 5 to <10m - Rigid structure or building
#27 5 to <10m - Unprotected safety barrier end
#28 5 to <10m - Low rigid object ≥20cm high
#29 5 to <10m - Aggressive vertical face
#30 5 to <10m - Upwards slope - roll over
#31 5 to <10m - Deep drainage ditch
#32 5 to <10m - Downwards slope
#33 5 to <10m - Safety barrier - concrete
#34 5 to <10m - Upwards slope - no roll over
#35 0 to <1m - Safety barrier - metal
#36 0 to <1m - Safety barrier - motorcycle friendly
#37 1 to <5m - Safety barrier - concrete
#38 1 to <5m - Semi-rigid structure or building
#39 1 to <5m - Safety barrier - metal
#40 1 to <5m - Safety barrier - motorcycle friendly
#41 1 to <5m - Safety barrier - wire rope
#42 1 to <5m - Safety barrier - wire rope
#43 ≥10m - Tree ≥10cm
#44 ≥10m - Rigid sign, post or pole ≥10cm
#45 ≥10m - Rigid structure or building
#46 ≥10m - Unprotected safety barrier end
#47 ≥10m - Low rigid object ≥20cm high
#48 ≥10m - Aggressive vertical face
#49 ≥10m - Deep drainage ditch
#50 5 to <10m - Safety barrier - concrete
#51 ≥10m - Upwards slope - roll over
#52 ≥10m - Downwards slope
#53 5 to <10m - Safety barrier - metal
#54 5 to <10m - Safety barrier - motorcycle friendly
#55 ≥10m - Upwards slope - no roll over
#56 ≥10m - No object
#57 5 to <10m - Safety barrier - wire rope
#58 ≥10m - Semi-rigid structure or building
#59 ≥10m - Safety barrier - concrete
#60 ≥10m - Safety barrier - metal
#61 ≥10m - Safety barrier - motorcycle friendly
#62 ≥10m - Safety barrier - wire rope
Please return the distance from the edge line of the nearest driving lane to the identified hazardous object(s) from <Categories> list.

categories.Category_description: Objects with effective distance of 0m to less than 1m from the edge line.
Object with effective distance of 1m to less than 5m from the edge line.
Object with effective distance of 5m to less than 10m from the edge line.
Object with effective distance equal or greater than 10m from the edge line.

attributes.Attribute description: Using <Attribute description> from 17. <Attribute>: Roadside severity - driver-side distance, please return object from <Categories> list that presents on image and has highest risk (this should be coresponded to Roadside severity - driver-side distance).

categories.Category_description: Cliff or equivalent hazard, such as the edge of a high bridge, that will result in certain fatality regardless of speed.
Tree trunk greater than 10cm in diameter.
Examples are lighting columns, metal or wood sign posts greater than 10cm diameter, rigid traffic signal posts greater than 10cm diameter or fence or other posts greater than 10cm diameter.

Aggressive ends to safety barriers.
Examples are ramped ends, unprotected ends, sharp ends or fish-tail terminals.
This category should also be used to record damaged sections of safety barrier.
Irregular rock face, wall or non-standard barrier.

Cut face of at least 2m height that is likely to cause a vehicle to roll over (15° to 75°), such as earth bound banks or grass banks.
If an upwards slope has an irregular rock faces, code it as an ‘aggressive vertical face’.
Ditch or culvert more than 1m deep.
Downwards slope from the roadway with an angle ratio greater than a 1:4 (equivalent to 25% gradient and 15°) and a drop of >1m.

Low rigid objects which are higher than a standard curb and may cause a vehicle to rollover if hit. Includes objects such as large rock or boulders, non-standard curbs (≥20cm high) or low barriers and walls (less than 67cm high).

Solid structures that will cause a rapid deceleration when hit.
Examples are reinforced concrete bridge supports, culvert headwalls, retaining walls or stone and concrete buildings.

Cut face of at least 2m height at a gradient of 75° or above, which a vehicle is likely to slide along when struck.
Irregular rock faces should not be recorded.

Solid structures that will likely deform slightly when hit.
Examples include houses and other similar buildings, street furniture such as bus shelters, communications cabinets or stone, masonry or brick boundary walls or fences.

Concrete safety barrier sufficient to restrain most cars and small vehicles.
Should be a continuous length of unbroken, undamaged safety barrier.

Metal safety barrier sufficient to restrain most cars and small vehicles (not wire rope safety barrier).
Should be a continuous length of unbroken, undamaged safety barrier.

Wire rope safety barrier sufficient to restrain most cars and small vehicles.
Should be a continuous length of unbroken, undamaged safety barrier.

Safety barrier designed specifically to restrain motorcycles. Should be a continuous length of unbroken, undamaged safety barrier.
Motorcycle friendly barriers will have some form of protection for the supporting posts or legs to minimise risk of injury to the rider.
No object within 20m of the road.

attributes.Attribute description:
Examine the roadside environment on the passenger-side of the image to identify hazardous objects that pose a risk to vehicles. Follow these steps:
1.Identify Hazardous Objects: Look for any objects on the passenger-side that could be dangerous to vehicles, such as barriers, trees, poles, structures, or slopes.
2. Measure Distance: Estimate the distance from the edge line of the nearest driving lane to the identified hazardous object(s).
3.Classify Hazards: Categorize the identified hazards using the provided risk hierarchy, with #1 being the highest risk:
#1 Any - Cliff
#2 0 to <1m - Tree ≥10cm
#3 0 to <1m - Rigid sign, post or pole ≥10cm
#4 0 to <1m - Rigid structure or building
#5 0 to <1m - Unprotected safety barrier end
#6 0 to <1m - Low rigid object ≥20cm high
#7 0 to <1m - Aggressive vertical face
#8 0 to <1m - Deep drainage ditch
#9 1 to <5m - Tree ≥10cm
#10 1 to <5m - Rigid sign, post or pole ≥10cm
#11 1 to <5m - Rigid structure or building
#12 1 to <5m - Unprotected safety barrier end
#13 1 to <5m - Low rigid object ≥20cm high
#14 0 to <1m - Upwards slope - roll over
#15 0 to <1m - Downwards slope
#16 1 to <5m - Aggressive vertical face
#17 1 to <5m - Deep drainage ditch
#18 0 to <1m - Upwards slope - no roll over
#19 0 to <1m - Upwards slope - roll over
#20 1 to <5m - Downwards slope
#21 0 to <1m - Upwards slope - no roll over
#22 0 to <1m - Semi-rigid structure or building
#23 1 to <5m - Semi-rigid structure or building
#24 5 to <10m - Tree ≥10cm
#25 5 to <10m - Rigid sign, post or pole ≥10cm
#26 5 to <10m - Rigid structure or building
#27 5 to <10m - Unprotected safety barrier end
#28 5 to <10m - Low rigid object ≥20cm high
#29 5 to <10m - Aggressive vertical face
#30 5 to <10m - Upwards slope - roll over
#31 5 to <10m - Deep drainage ditch
#32 5 to <10m - Downwards slope
#33 5 to <10m - Safety barrier - concrete
#34 5 to <10m - Upwards slope - no roll over
#35 0 to <1m - Safety barrier - metal
#36 0 to <1m - Safety barrier - motorcycle friendly
#37 1 to <5m - Safety barrier - concrete
#38 1 to <5m - Semi-rigid structure or building
#39 1 to <5m - Safety barrier - metal
#40 1 to <5m - Safety barrier - motorcycle friendly
#41 1 to <5m - Safety barrier - wire rope
#42 1 to <5m - Safety barrier - wire rope
#43 ≥10m - Tree ≥10cm
#44 ≥10m - Rigid sign, post or pole ≥10cm
#45 ≥10m - Rigid structure or building
#46 ≥10m - Unprotected safety barrier end
#47 ≥10m - Low rigid object ≥20cm high
#48 ≥10m - Aggressive vertical face
#49 ≥10m - Deep drainage ditch
#50 5 to <10m - Safety barrier - concrete
#51 ≥10m - Upwards slope - roll over
#52 ≥10m - Downwards slope
#53 5 to <10m - Safety barrier - metal
#54 5 to <10m - Safety barrier - motorcycle friendly
#55 ≥10m - Upwards slope - no roll over
#56 ≥10m - No object
#57 5 to <10m - Safety barrier - wire rope
#58 ≥10m - Semi-rigid structure or building
#59 ≥10m - Safety barrier - concrete
#60 ≥10m - Safety barrier - metal
#61 ≥10m - Safety barrier - motorcycle friendly
#62 ≥10m - Safety barrier - wire rope
Please return the distance from the edge line of the nearest driving lane to the identified hazardous object(s) from <Categories> list.

categories.Category_description: Objects on passenger-side with effective distance of 0m to less than 1m from the edge line.
Object on passenger-side with effective distance of 1m to less than 5m from the edge line.
Object on passenger-side with effective distance of 5m to less than 10m from the edge line.
Object with effective distance equal or greater than 10m from the edge line.

attributes.Attribute description: Using <Attribute description> from 19. <Attribute>: Roadside severity - passenger-side distance, please return object from <Categories> list that presents on image and has highest risk (this should be coresponded to Roadside severity - passenger-side distance).

categories.Category_description: Cliff or equivalent hazard, such as the edge of a high bridge, that will result in certain fatality regardless of speed.
Tree trunk greater than 10cm in diameter.
Examples are lighting columns, metal or wood sign posts greater than 10cm diameter, rigid traffic signal posts greater than 10cm diameter or fence or other posts greater than 10cm diameter.

Aggressive ends to safety barriers.
Examples are ramped ends, unprotected ends, sharp ends or fish-tail terminals.
This category should also be used to record damaged sections of safety barrier.
Irregular rock face, wall or non-standard barrier.

Cut face of at least 2m height that is likely to cause a vehicle to roll over (15° to 75°), such as earth bound banks or grass banks.
If an upwards slope has an irregular rock faces, code it as an ‘aggressive vertical face’.
Ditch or culvert more than 1m deep.
Downwards slope from the roadway with an angle ratio greater than a 1:4 (equivalent to 25% gradient and 15°) and a drop of >1m.

Low rigid objects which are higher than a standard curb and may cause a vehicle to rollover if hit. Includes objects such as large rock or boulders, non-standard curbs (≥20cm high) or low barriers and walls (less than 67cm high).

Solid structures that will cause a rapid deceleration when hit.
Examples are reinforced concrete bridge supports, culvert headwalls, retaining walls or stone and concrete buildings.

Cut face of at least 2m height at a gradient of 75° or above, which a vehicle is likely to slide along when struck.
Irregular rock faces should not be recorded.

Solid structures that will likely deform slightly when hit.
Examples include houses and other similar buildings, street furniture such as bus shelters, communications cabinets or stone, masonry or brick boundary walls or fences.

Concrete safety barrier sufficient to restrain most cars and small vehicles.
Should be a continuous length of unbroken, undamaged safety barrier.

Metal safety barrier sufficient to restrain most cars and small vehicles (not wire rope safety barrier).
Should be a continuous length of unbroken, undamaged safety barrier.

Wire rope safety barrier sufficient to restrain most cars and small vehicles.
Should be a continuous length of unbroken, undamaged safety barrier.

Safety barrier designed specifically to restrain motorcycles. Should be a continuous length of unbroken, undamaged safety barrier.
Motorcycle friendly barriers will have some form of protection for the supporting posts or legs to minimise risk of injury to the rider.
No object within 20m of the road.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record any textured markings running along a road which function to warn drivers leaving the lane on the passenger-side of the roadway.
Shoulder rumble strips are also known as raised profile markings. This feature provides an audio-vibratory warning to the driver.
Shoulder rumble strips will only be found on paved shoulders and should be a continuous, unbroken line.
Rumble strips may be either grooves cut into the pavement surface or raised ribs added to the road marking. Raised markers that are spaced between 10-20 cm and serve a similar purpose may also be recorded.
Shoulder rumble strips should be coded when a carriageway has rumble for both passenger-side and driver-side edge lines (regardless of whether the carriageway is divided or undivided). Do not record centre line rumble strips here.
Shoulder rumble strips should only be recorded where delineation is present.

categories.Category_description: No shoulder rumble strip present.
Shoulder rumble strip present.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the width of the safe and drivable section of road from the edge line to the edge of the paving.
Code this for driver-side.
A narrow paved shoulder shall be recorded wherever an edge marking is present even if the edge line is very close to the pavement edge.
If paving begins to break up on a shoulder, the paved shoulder width should be measured up to where the edge break occurs.
If a road has no markings for a shoulder (no edge line), then no paved shoulder should be recorded, since a vehicle is able to travel to the edge of the sealed surface.
Paved shoulder width on divided and undivided roads.
 For a divided carriageway, driver-side paved shoulder width is the distance from the edge line to the edge of the median. For an undivided carriageway, driver-side paved shoulder width is the distance from the edge line to the edge of the paving on the other side of the road.

categories.Category_description: There is no paved shoulder (no edge line present).
Paved shoulder is 0m to less than 1.0m (edge line is present).
Paved shoulder is 1m to less than 2.4m (edge line is present).
Paved shoulder is greater than 2.4m (edge line is present).

attributes.Attribute description: Please refer to <Attribute description> in Paved shoulder - driver-side. Record this <Attibute> for the passenger-side of the road.

categories.Category_description: There is no paved shoulder (no edge line present).
Paved shoulder is 0m to less than 1.0m (edge line is present).
Paved shoulder is 1m to less than 2.4m (edge line is present).
Paved shoulder is greater than 2.4m (edge line is present).

attributes.Attribute description: Record the presence and type of intersections. Do not record property access points, unless they are large enough that turning bays or traffic signals are present. For more information on how to code urban laneways, see <Attribute description> in 28. <Attribute>: Property access points to choose if it is intersection or property access points.

categories.Category_description: Four or more leg intersection or crossroads with no signals or a protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic).
Four or more leg intersection or crossroads with a protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic) but no signals.
Four or more intersection or crossroads with signals but no protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic).
Three leg intersection or T-junction with no protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic) or signals.
Three leg intersection or T-junction with a protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic) but no signals.

Small roundabout with a radius of less than 4m typically found in low speed urban areas. Mini-roundabouts have a central circular island that is flush with the road surface (or slightly raised) and are commonly constructed using a white road marking or other coloured surface.
Three leg intersection with signals but no protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic).
Four or more leg intersection or crossroads with a protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic) and signals.
Three leg intersection or T-junction with a protected turn lane (crossing opposing traffic) and signals.
Circular intersection that flows in a single direction about a central island of 4m radius or more.
An at-grade railway crossing with give way or stop signage only (or no signage).

Merge lane for traffic entering the road. Merge lanes typically occur at grade separated intersections.
Do not code filter lanes (intersection channelization) or exit (diverge) lanes where vehicles are exiting the road.
Only record the merge lane once - even if it spans two coding segments.
An at-grade railway crossing with a physical device to warn of an approaching train (flashing lights and/or boom gates).

An informal U-turn location without acceleration or deceleration lanes and/or with poor condition pavement surface. These median crossings have not been formally designed but rather developed informally overtime through regular local use.

A formal (designed) U-turn location. Appropriate acceleration and deceleration lanes may or may not be present. Record this detail plus condition of median pavement surface under ‘intersection quality’.
No intersection present.

attributes.Attribute description: Record if there are raised islands or coloured hatching present at an intersection that designate intended vehicle paths. Do not code informal channelization, for example, where vehicles regularly cut a corner or there is more than one entry to a side road. Channelization is the separation or regulation of conflicting traffic movements into defined paths of travel. Traffic islands or pavement markings are used to facilitate the safe and orderly movements of both vehicles and pedestrians. Channelization is primarily used to separate turning movements from through movements. If 24. <Attribute>: Intersection type is recored 'None', this attribute should be coded as 'Not present'.

categories.Category_description: No channelization present at an intersection.
Channelization present with either raised or coloured islands that designate the intended vehicle path.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record an estimate of the AADT of the intersecting road.
Where volume data or local knowledge is not available, estimates of the intersecting road volume can be made using aerial photo maps (within the inspection system software or software like Google Earth). The estimate should consider what towns, villages, or cities the intersecting road connects to, and development along the intersecting road.
For railway crossings an estimate of the number of trains running through the crossing per day is required. If 24. <Attribute>: Intersection type is not 'None', this attribute should be coded as one of these options {≥15,000 vehicles,10,000 to 15,000 vehicles,5,000 to 10,000 vehicles,1,000 to 5,000 vehicles,100 to 1,000 vehicles,1 to 100 vehicles}, which deatials are avaliable in <Category description>. If 24. <Attribute>: Intersection type is recored 'None', this attribute should be coded as 'Not applicable'

categories.Category_description: Over 15,000 vehicles per day (vpd). Where volume data or local knowledge is not available, assume over 15,000 vpd where the intersecting road is: Divided with three or more lanes provided for side road traffic in each direction; or Multi-lane merge lanes associated with grade separated intersections.

10,000 to 15,000 vehicles per day (vpd). Where volume data or local knowledge is not available, assume 10,000 to 15,000 vpd where the intersecting road is undivided with three or more lanes provided for side road traffic in each direction, or single lane merge lanes associated with grade separated intersections.

5,000 to 10,000 vehicles per day (vpd). Where volume data or local knowledge is not available, assume 5,000 to 10,000 vpd where the intersecting road is undivided with two lanes provided for side road traffic in each direction.

1,000 to 5,000 vehicles per day (vpd). Where volume data or local knowledge is not available, assume 1,000 to 5,000 vpd where the intersecting road is undivided with one lane provided for side road traffic in each direction.
100 to 1,000 vehicles per day (vpd). Where volume data or local knowledge is not available, assume 100 to 1,000 vpd where the intersecting road is a paved undivided road.

Up to 100 vehicles per day (vpd). Where volume data or local knowledge is not available, assume 1 to 100 vpd where the intersecting road is a single-track (one-lane) undivided, unpaved road. Can also be used for very low flow intersections in remote rural areas.
No intersecting road.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the quality of the intersection design, advance warning, signing, and markings.
Intersection quality is an indication of how well a driver can anticipate intersection conditions and prepare accordingly. Factors that contribute to ‘poor’ intersection quality may include:
• Very short merge lanes
• Poor deflection angles at roundabouts (where the approach means roundabout can be entered at high speeds)
• Lack of advance signing and marking on an intersection approach where the intersection is not clearly visible to approaching drivers (i.e. where approach sight distance is limited)
• Lack of facilities for motorcycles, pedestrians and bicycles.
Intersection quality is factored into motorcycle, pedestrian and bicycle Star Ratings. For an intersection to be considered adequate, vehicle drivers must also be able to anticipate the presence and movements of other road user groups and vice versa. The examples below demonstrate the difference between a ‘poor quality’ intersection and an intersection of ‘adequate quality’ where on-road markings improve visibility and turning movements for motorcycles and bicycles. If 24. <Attribute>: Intersection type is recored 'None', this <Attribute> is 'Not applicable'.

categories.Category_description: Intersection design is poor. Necessary signs and markings are absent, sight distance is limited or obstructed, and/or roads and conflicting traffic flows do not intersect at right angles. Has inadequate facilities for motorcyclists, pedestrians and bicyclists.
Intersection design is adequate. Necessary signing and markings are present. Has adequate facilities for motorcyclists, pedestrians and bicyclists.
No intersection present.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the number of commercial and residential driveways and minor access lanes.
This includes any points where vehicles can enter or exit the roadway other than public roads. This may include entries to large carparks, parkland, rest areas and laneways.
Do not record a property access point which is large enough that turning bays or traffic signals are present. In this case, it should be coded as an intersection under 24.<Attribute>: Intersections .
Do not record temporary entries, such as for construction, or controlled entries where gates are present.
How do I code urban laneways? Some cities have extra large city blocks that feature extensive laneway networks, which provide access to local residences and businesses. Entries to these laneways may be considered a property access point or an intersecting street, depending on several characteristics. The table below gives a general guide on when a laneway is a property access point and when it is considered an intersecting road. Characteristics are listed in priority order. 
Record as an intersecting road 1) If the intersection has regular features, such as turning bays or traffic signals, or intersecting traffic has access to both directions of travel. 2) Laneway provides through access, serves as a trunk route for other laneways, or provides access to a large area of residential and commercial development. and 3) Two cars can pass or traffic is more than 100 vehicles per day.
Record as a property access point 1) No intersection features; access to side road only or only one direction of travel. 2) Laneway provides limited access to residential and commercial establishments. 3) Two cars would be unable to pass or traffic is less than 100 vehicles per day.

categories.Category_description: One or more commercial access points within the coding segment. Includes service stations, shops and roadside cafes, small carparks and rest stops. May also include entrances to industrial sites such as quarries or mining sites.
Three or more residential access points or an access point that serves three or more residential properties.

Less than three residential access points or an access point that serves three or less residential properties. May also include minor farm accesses and other minor tracks used by motor vehicles to gain occasional access to the main carriageway.
No residential or commercial access points.

attributes.Attribute description:
Please count the number of traffic lanes in the image in the direction of travel.

Instructions:

- Use the lane markings to determine the number of lanes. For example, if there are two visible lane markings, there should be three lanes.
- Do not count turning lanes at intersections.
- Do count any bus or transit lanes that are part of the main carriageway.
- If there are no lane markings, estimate the number of lanes by dividing the total road width by the typical width of one lane.
- Provide a clear answer with the total number of lanes counted.

categories.Category_description: Four or more lanes in direction of travel.
Three lanes in direction of travel.

Undivided road only
Three lanes in one direction and two in the other direction.
Two lanes in direction of travel.

Undivided road only
Two lanes in one direction and one in the other direction.
One lane in direction of travel.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the distance from the centre of the edge line to the centre of the adjacent lane marking. If the road has no edge line, the lane width is measured from the edge of the pavement to the adjacent lane marking. For roads with one lane in each direction, the adjacent lane marking will be the centre line.
Where lane width varies, record the narrowest lane width.
If no lane markings are present, the total road width should be divided by the number of traffic streams to determine the lane width. 
Lane width approximations: in the absence of exact lane measurements, lane width can be approximated using typical vehicles sizes. For the purposes of estimation, the typical widths of vehicles are as follows:
• Truck or bus = 2.5m
• Tractor = 2.3m
• Van/minibus = 2m
• Family car = 1.8m
• Light 3- or 4-wheeled motorised vehicle = 1.2m
A truck or lorry would struggle to fit in a narrow lane, comfortably fit in a medium lane, and have ample space on each side in a wide lane.

categories.Category_description: Lane width is less than 2.75m.
Lane width is from 2.75m to 3.25m.
Lane width is greater than 3.25m.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the horizontal alignment of the road.
Curvature is gauged according to approximate curve radius and the appropriate safe approach and driven speed under normal conditions. It may also be collected from sensors built into an inspection system, for example accelerometer and gyroscopic data.
Record each curve from its start point to end point, even if this spans several coding segments.
If there is an advisory speed sign, use the marked speed for rating the horizontal alignment. Do not use the speed of the inspection vehicle since this can be affected by other factors, such as traffic flow.
If the road is straight, record it as ‘straight or gently curving’.
Do not code curvature associated with roundabouts or other intersection related road alignment modifications, unless the curve precedes the roundabout as a traffic calming measure or as a natural characteristic of the road.

categories.Category_description: A curve that can only be driven at less than 40km/h with an approximate radius of less than 200m.
A curve that can only be driven between 40km/h and 70km/h with an approximate radius of 200m to 400m.
A curve that can be driven between 70km/h and 100km/h with an approximate radius of curve 400m to 800m.
A straight road or curve that can be driven at 100km/h or more with an approximate radius of curve greater than 800m.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record how easy it is to judge how sharp a curve is and if it can be driven safely.
The quality of the curve will reflect the extent to which signs and markings help the driver to judge the correct curvature, and the sight distance in advance of, and around, the curve.
A practical indication of the quality of the curve might be whether the driver needs to adjust speed suddenly or unexpectedly on the approach to, or within the curve. This may occur even though there has been an attempt through signing to warn the driver of extra risk.
Apply the same quality of curve code to the whole curve, from its start point to its end point.

categories.Category_description: A curve where rapid or unexpected speed adjustments are needed to negotiate the curve, and there is a lack of advanced signing and/or missing or poorly maintained road markings.
Signing, marking and sight distance enable a driver to judge curvature. Curves of adequate quality may incorporate chevron alignment markers (CAMs) or other reflective hazard markers.
The road is straight or gently curving.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the gradient of the road along its length.
Grade refers to both upward and downward slopes.

categories.Category_description:
A steep rise of 10m or more over a 100m length, or an angle of 5.75 degrees or above.
This grade would typically be encountered in mountainous terrain or short, steep sections in rolling terrain.

A moderate rise of 7.5m to <10m over a 100m length, or an angle of 4.3 to <5.75 degrees.
This grade would typically be encountered in rolling, hill or foothill terrain, and in moderately sloping sections of mountainous terrain.

Flat or gentle rise of 0m to <7.5m over a 100m length, or an angle of 0 to <4.3 degrees.
This grade would typically be encountered in level or gently rolling terrain.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the condition of the road surface.
This includes the ability of the road to provide a level, even running surface that is free from major surface defects that may adversely affect the vehicle path.
Record a ‘poor’ or ‘medium’ road condition if defects are present for 10m or more at any point on a coding segment.
Defects that should be considered to include anything that would cause an impact on vehicle control or path, some examples are:
• Deformation of the tarmac, including rutting or uneven surface.
• Holes in the road surface due to loss of material which is sufficiently wide or deep enough to cause a severe jolt or loss of control to the vehicle.
• Edge defects including any road shoulder seal problems which encroach on the driven lane or that would require small vehicles using the road shoulder to enter regular traffic lanes.

categories.Category_description: Road has serious defects which are likely to result in frequent or unpredictable impact on vehicle control or on motorcyclists and bicyclists.
Road has a number of minor defects which may result in occasional impact on vehicle control or path or on motorcyclists and bicyclists.
Road has very few or no defects and is adequate for all road users. There is no potential impact on vehicle control or path or on motorcyclists and bicyclists.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the skidding resistance and texture depth of the road surface.
Surface texture deficiencies includes surface friction issues such as loose gravel, flushing or stripping which could reduce traction for vehicles in wet or dry conditions.
The attribute recorded should reflect the general condition of the road for the majority of the coding segment.

categories.Category_description:
The road surface is unpaved and has a low grip surface.
For example, the surface is covered in loose gravel, or a natural surface is likely to be slippery in wet conditions (e.g. silt/clay surfaces).

The road surface is unpaved with a relatively good surface grip.
For example, the surface is compacted aggregate providing a surface that remains firm in all prevailing weather conditions.

The road surface is sealed but has a low grip surface.
For example, the road surface is paved and looks smooth and shiny for more than 20% of the preferred vehicle path, or loose gravel or other material is present for more than 20%.

The road surface is sealed and has a medium grip surface.
For example, the road surface is paved and looks smooth and shiny for up to 20% of the preferred vehicle path, or loose gravel or other material is present for up to 20%.
The road surface is sealed and is expected to have adequate skid resistance performance. There are no visible smooth and shiny sections in the preferred vehicle path.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the adequacy of road lines and markings.
Delineation should inform drivers of road conditions to keep them within the driven lane, aware of road and intersection conditions in advance and in location and provide clear visible indications of the presence and path of motorcyclists and bicyclists where appropriate.
The delineation is based on a combination of the following factors:
• Centre lines, lane markers and edge lines
• Guideposts and delineators, road studs and hazard markers, and
• Signage (on road and posted) within an appropriate distance of the approach.
Warning signs must be present to warn drivers of any sudden change in the road conditions, such as lane narrowing.
What is an appropriate distance for warning signs ahead of hazards and other road conditions? Warning or directional signs are placed well ahead of points of interest (e.g. an intersection or rail crossing) or hazard to give drivers adequate warning. This may mean that the sign warning of a hazard is in a different coding segment. The distance is generally determined by the traffic speed. The specifications will vary from country to country, however, as a general guide:
• Less than 30km/h (20mph): At location
• 30km/h - 50km/h (20mph - 30mph): 5m - 75m
• 50km/h - 80km/h (30mph - 50mph): 50m - 200m
• 80km/h -100km/h (50mph - 60mph): 150m - 250m >100km/h (>60mph): 200m - 400m
For urban road assessments, curbs and channelization may be considered in place of edge lines where vehicle parking, paved shoulder or on road bicycle or motorcycle lanes are not present.
Delineation, particularly the presence and quality of reflective signs and markers, is important for safety at night.
‘Poor’ or ‘adequate’ delineation should be consistent with that recorded as part of quality of curve, intersections and pedestrian crossings.

categories.Category_description: Signing of hazards, or centre and edge markings are generally absent or in poor condition.
Signs warning of severe hazards, and centre and edge markings are generally present and visible.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the presence of street lighting.
A street light or street lamp is a raised source of light often mounted on a lamp column or pole either on the side of the road or within the median or suspended on a wire above the road to provide illumination. 
Street lighting should be sufficient enough to provide illumination of and for pedestrians and bicyclists.

categories.Category_description: Street lighting is not present or is insufficient.
Street light is present that is sufficient to illuminate pedestrians and bicyclists.

attributes.Attribute description: Record the presence of purpose-built pedestrian crossing facilities on the inspected road. If there are two or more pedestrian crossing facilities at an intersection of the inspected road (or more than one intersection), record the one with highest risk. Record the one which presents higher risk (or first in the direction of travel if both the same).

categories.Category_description: No provision for pedestrians crossing.
Pedestrian central refuge island is provided. Do not code poorly designed refuge islands or medians of insufficient width or protection.
Clearly-marked pedestrian crossing without a refuge island. Not signalised.
Unmarked crossing with a raised (speed reducing) platform without a refuge island. Pedestrians typically give way to cars on this type of crossing.
Clearly-marked pedestrian crossing with refuge island.
Unmarked crossing with a raised (speed reducing) platform and refuge island. Pedestrians typically give way to cars on this type of crossing.
Clearly-marked pedestrian crossing with a raised (speed reducing) platform without a refuge island.
Clearly-marked pedestrian crossing with a raised (speed reducing) platform and refuge island.

Designated pedestrian crossing with traffic signals that control pedestrian and vehicle movements. Only record a signalised crossing facility where pedestrian-specific signals are present and provide a pedestrian phase.

Designated pedestrian crossing with refuge island and traffic signals that control pedestrian and vehicle movements. Only record a signalised crossing facility where pedestrian-specific signals are present and provide a pedestrian phase.

A physically separated pedestrian crossing that does not bring pedestrians into conflict with road traffic flows. May include pedestrian overbridges or underpasses (subways).
Do not code grade separated facilities if pedestrians cross at street level.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record effectiveness of the pedestrian crossing on the inspected road or side road.
If two pedestrian crossings are recorded within one coding segment and are of different standard, record the one of lower quality. If quality of side road crossings cannot be ascertained from the image, record the quality for crossings on the inspected road only.
Record pedestrian crossing quality wherever a pedestrian crossing facility is recorded on the inspected road. ‘Poor’ or ‘adequate’ pedestrian crossing quality should consider other relevant attributes such as delineation, street lighting, sight distance, and intersection quality (where it is located at an intersection).

categories.Category_description: The pedestrian crossing facility is ineffective. Vehicle drivers do not stop or give pedestrian right-of-way, the facility is not clearly visible or cannot be anticipated by vehicle drivers, and/or the facility is obstructed.

The pedestrian crossing is effective. Vehicle drivers stop and give pedestrians right-of-way, the facility is clearly visible and can be anticipated by vehicle drivers, and the facility is not obstructed.
No pedestrian crossing facility is present.

attributes.Attribute description: Record the presence of purpose-built pedestrian crossing facilities on the side (intersecting) road. If there are two or more pedestrian crossing facilities at an intersection of the inspected road (or more than one intersection), record the one with highest risk. Record the one in the direction of travel.

categories.Category_description: No provision for pedestrians crossing.
Pedestrian central refuge island is provided. Do not code poorly designed refuge islands or medians of insufficient width or protection.
Clearly-marked pedestrian crossing without a refuge island. Not signalised.
Unmarked crossing with a raised (speed reducing) platform without a refuge island. Pedestrians typically give way to cars on this type of crossing.
Clearly-marked pedestrian crossing with refuge island.
Unmarked crossing with a raised (speed reducing) platform and refuge island. Pedestrians typically give way to cars on this type of crossing.
Clearly-marked pedestrian crossing with a raised (speed reducing) platform without a refuge island.
Clearly-marked pedestrian crossing with a raised (speed reducing) platform and refuge island.

Designated pedestrian crossing with traffic signals that control pedestrian and vehicle movements. Only record a signalised crossing facility where pedestrian-specific signals are present and provide a pedestrian phase.

Designated pedestrian crossing with refuge island and traffic signals that control pedestrian and vehicle movements.
Only record a signalised crossing facility where pedestrian-specific signals are present and provide a pedestrian phase.

A physically separated pedestrian crossing that does not bring pedestrians into conflict with road traffic flows. May include pedestrian overbridges or underpasses (subways). Do not code grade separated facilities if pedestrians cross at street level.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the presence pedestrian fencing or other barriers which effectively control pedestrian crossing flow.
Pedestrian fencing may be in the form of safety barriers, regular fences (non-safety barrier) or other forms of barriers such as shrubs and hedges.
Pedestrian fencing/barriers can be on one or both sides or the middle of a road.
Do not code pedestrian fencing where there is evidence that pedestrians traverse through or over the fence/barrier.
Pedestrian fencing should be present for the whole coding segment except where an at-grade pedestrian crossing is present.

categories.Category_description: Pedestrian fencing/barriers are incomplete or ineffective.
Pedestrian fencing is complete and effective. Pedestrian fencing can be on one or two sides or in the centre of the road.

attributes.Attribute description: Record the presence of road infrastructure features that will typically reduce the operating speed by 5km/h to 10km/h below the speed limit. Features may include curb build-outs, speed humps, raised tables, entry treatments, speed cushions, chicanes and modified intersections. Do not record roundabouts or mini-roundabouts. Do not record speed cameras. Speed cameras are only considered effective tools for enforcing the posted speed, not reducing it to below the posted speed.

categories.Category_description: Speed management features present and sufficient to reduce the operating speed 5-10km/h below the speed limit.
No speed management features present.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the extent of vehicle parking along the side of the road.
Vehicle parking includes parked vehicles and on-street parking spaces (even if no vehicles are present), bus stop bays, taxi ranks, and any other designated places where vehicles can stop on the side of the road (such as emergency stopping lanes) within 2m of the outside edge of the driveable lane.
For cities and urban environments, on-street parking may be assumed if space is available and where parking restrictions are either not present or present but not enforced. Vehicle parking can also vary significantly depending on the time of day and on the surrounding land-use and road functions. Land-use data and local knowledge may be used to record vehicle parking.

categories.Category_description: Vehicles park on both sides of the road.
Vehicles park on one side of the road.
No vehicle parking present.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the presence of pedestrian sidewalks on the driver-side of the road.
A sidewalk is a purpose-built facility for pedestrians that has an all-weather surface (sealed or unsealed) and which provides a reliable surface and space for pedestrians to walk.
Do not code paved shoulders or pedestrian crossing facilities here.
Do not code a sidewalk that is not continuous over the entire length of the coding segment.
Measuring sidewalk distance is based on the sidewalk’s distance from the nearest driving lane, and if there is a vertical barrier separating moving vehicles and pedestrians. This distance is measured from the edge-line of the nearest driving lane to the edge of the sidewalk, including the paved shoulder and vehicle parking (if present). 
What is an informal path? Informal paths include:
• Observed or evidence of pedestrian flow along the side of the road where there is no purpose-built sidewalk; or
• Where a sidewalk is partially blocked by vehicles or other obstructions, but where pedestrians are not forced to walk on the roadway.
Where pedestrians are using a separated (off-road) bicycle path or designated shared-use path, record it as both a sidewalk and a bicycle facility.

categories.Category_description: Pedestrian access not possible, restricted or pedestrians are forced to walk on the roadway; no discernible sidewalk is provided, sidewalk is not usable or sufficient to cater for demand; and/or pedestrians are using road lanes, paved shoulder, motorcycle facilities or on-road bicycle facilities.
An informal path only, with a distance of less than 1m from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).
An informal path only, with a distance of 1m or more from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).
Sidewalk is present and free of obstruction, with a distance of less than 1m from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).
Sidewalk is present and free of obstruction, with a distance of 1m to 3m from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).
Sidewalk is present and free of obstruction, with a distance of 3m or more from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).

Sidewalk is present and free of obstruction, with a physical barrier separating it from the nearest driving lane. A physical barrier must be sufficient to restrain a vehicle from entering the pedestrian facility at the posted speed limit. Depending on the posted speed, this may include hedges and small shrubs, bollards, fences, walls, and safety barriers. Curbs are not considered a physical barrier.

attributes.Attribute description: Please refer to <Attribute description> in Sidewalk - driver-side but for the passenger-side of the road.

categories.Category_description: Pedestrian access not possible, restricted or pedestrians are forced to walk on the roadway; no discernible sidewalk is provided, sidewalk is not usable or sufficient to cater for demand; and/or pedestrians are using road lanes, paved shoulder, motorcycle facilities or on-road bicycle facilities.
An informal path only, with a distance of less than 1m from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).
An informal path only, with a distance of 1m or more from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).
Sidewalk is present and free of obstruction, with a distance of less than 1m from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).
Sidewalk is present and free of obstruction, with a distance of 1m to 3m from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).
Sidewalk is present and free of obstruction, with a distance of 3m or more from the nearest driving lane (no barrier).

Sidewalk is present and free of obstruction, with a physical barrier separating it from the nearest driving lane. A physical barrier must be sufficient to restrain a vehicle from entering the pedestrian facility at the posted speed limit. Depending on the posted speed, this may include hedges and small shrubs, bollards, fences, walls, and safety barriers. Curbs are not considered a physical barrier.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the presence of a service road running parallel with the main carriageway.
If the carriageway being coded is the service road, record the service road as being 'Not present'.
The purpose of a service road is to link the property accesses and minor intersections together and then join them to the main carriageway at a single point.
For undivided roads, record service roads which appear on either one side or both sides of the road.

categories.Category_description: Service road is not present (or carriageway being coded is the service road).
Service road is present.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the presence of purpose-built facilities for motorcycles, mopeds and other light motorised vehicles capable of speeds of 30km/h or more.
For undivided roads, record motorcycle facilities which appear on either one side or both sides of the road.
Is a service road a motorcycle facility? No. Service roads can be used by all road users. If use of a side road is restricted (by design or enforcement) to two- or three-wheeled motorised vehicles and bicycles, it should be coded as a motorcycle facility. Even where a service road is used primarily by two- and three-wheelers, only record a motorcycle facility where one of the following attributes is present.

categories.Category_description: No specific provisions for motorised two- and three-wheelers.
Dedicated motorcycle lane separated from the nearest driving lane by road markings.

categories.Category: Segregated one-way motorcycle path without barrier
categories.Category_description: Motorcycle path separated from the nearest driving lane by at least a 1m wide curb or equivalent raised surface (no barrier).

categories.Category: Segregated two-way motorcycle path with barrier
categories.Category_description: Two-way motorcycle path separated from traffic by at least a 1m wide curb or equivalent raised surface (no barrier).

categories.Category: Segregated two-way motorcycle path with barrier
categories.Category_description:
Two-way segregated motorcycle path separated by a physical barrier or located at least 10m from the nearest driving lane.
A physical barrier must be sufficient enough to fully restrict vehicles from entering the dedicated path at the posted speed.

categories.Category: Segregated one-way motorcycle path with barrier
categories.Category_description:
Segregated motorcycle path separated by a physical barrier or located at least 10m from the nearest driving lane.
A physical barrier must be sufficient enough to fully restrict vehicles from entering the dedicated path at the posted speed.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record purpose-built facilities for bicyclists.
Only record facilities which are specifically for bicycles (and in some cases, also for pedestrians) that are present for the whole coding segment.
Do not code facilities which are being used by motorised or electric powered two- or three-wheeled vehicles travelling at or above 30km/h.
For undivided roads, code bicycle facilities which appear on either one side or both sides of the road.
Do not code bicycle facilities that are of poor standard. This may include facilities that are:
• Inappropriate to a high speed environment
• Of inadequate width (for example, where a bicycle is painted onto a narrow and poorly maintained paved shoulder or the existing facility cannot cater for peak hour flows)
• Not continuous for the entire coding segment or have localised pinch points of less than 1.2m in width, or
• In conflict with other uses, such as merge lanes, parked vehicles or bus stops.
Bicycle facilities may be provided alongside pedestrian sidewalks. Where a bicycle facility is shared with pedestrians, code it as a shared use path.

categories.Category_description: No specific provision for bicycles, or existing facilities are of poor standard.
No specific provision for bicycles, but which is signed as preferred bicycle route.
The outer most lane is equal or greater than 4.2m in width. The lane may or may not have bicycle markings or signage. Do not code the road shoulder or where traffic speeds are 50km/h or more.

A dedicated bicycle lane separated from traffic by lane markings on the roadway or by <1m of raised or paved surface. An on-road lane should be appropriate to the traffic speed environment; be of adequate width, well maintained surface, and have little or no conflict with other uses, such as merge lanes, parked vehicles or bus stops.
Bicycles have access to a path shared with pedestrians, which is separated from traffic by ≥1m raised or paved surface.
A dedicated bicycle path separated from traffic by ≥1m raised or paved surface.

A dedicated bicycle path separated from traffic by a physical barrier or is located ≥10m from the road.
A physical barrier must be sufficient to restrain a vehicle from entering the bicycle facility at the posted speed limit.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the presence of major road construction or road works in progress.
Record any construction activities in the vicinity of the road that impacts on its normal operation, such as temporary speed limits or lane closures.

categories.Category_description: Major road works are when the road is being significantly changed and the attribute cannot be coded accurately. Star ratings will not be generated for these segments.

Minor road works are when all the attributes can be coded accurately even though there are road works.
Road works and temporary traffic management may affect the speed of passing traffic.
No construction or road works in progress.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the ability of a driver to see and/or anticipate road conditions and other road users ahead.
This includes seeing pedestrians or bicyclists on the roadway or about to cross the road ahead, or other vehicles at an intersection. Horizontal and vertical alignment or physical obstructions such as roadside objects and vegetation may reduce sight distance.
As a general guide, sight distance is considered poor if it is:
- Less than 50m for speeds of 70km/h or less, or
- Less than 80m for speeds above 70km/h.

categories.Category_description: Sight distance is limited or restricted.
Sight distance is not limited or restricted.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the presence of a school zone.
Record the school zone from it start point to end point, as designated by the signs on both approaches to the school, even if this spans several coding segments.
What is a school zone? School zones are areas within the vicinity of schools and other educational establishments where school children and young pedestrians are likely to be present in high numbers. School zones are likely to have reduced speed limits for certain times of the day. School zones are likely to have appropriate road signs and markings to make motorists aware of the presence of vulnerable road users such as young pedestrians and bicyclists. Parking restrictions may also apply in school zones.

categories.Category_description: School is present but without school zone warning signs or markings.

categories.Category: School zone static signs or road markings
categories.Category_description:
A school zone is present with appropriate warning signs.
Road markings and speed limit signs may also be present.
A school zone is present and incorporates flashing beacons to give emphasis to the warning signs and appropriate speed limit.

categories.Category: Not applicable (no school at the location)
categories.Category_description: No school at the location.

attributes.Attribute description:
Record the presence of a crossing supervisor or warden.
A crossing supervisor/patrol assists children in safely crossing roads on their way to and from school. School crossing supervisors often operate during the school community's peak demand period both in the morning and in the afternoon.
Actual operating times depend on a number of factors that include school start times, pedestrian access and traffic volumes.
If crossing is supervised on an ad hoc or irregular basis, record as ‘not present’.
Local knowledge or site observations may be required.

categories.Category: School zone crossing supervisor not present
categories.Category_description: A crossing supervisor/patrol is not present or only present on an irregular basis.

categories.Category: School zone crossing supervisor present at school start and finish times
categories.Category_description: A crossing supervisor/patrol is present. The crossing supervisor may be present throughout the school day or during periods of high pedestrian activity only, for example at school start and finish times.

categories.Category: Not applicable (no school at the location)
categories.Category_description: No school pedestrian crossing facility at the location.
